summary.notes: This classification uses folder/filename heuristics (globs and representative samples). If you want a literal entry for every single file, I can expand this into a full list (it will be large).

keep.description: Core application files required for runtime and development.

move_to_archive.description: Large vendor copies, bundled libraries, or experimental materials that shouldn't live in source tree but may be kept for reference.

candidate_for_deletion.description: Duplicative docs, logs, and build artifacts that safely can be removed (or archived off-repo).

needs_review.description: Files that require manual inspection before action because they may be important but are ambiguous (custom scripts, notebooks, large datasets).

items.issue: Possible secrets committed. Rotate any secrets and remove the file from git history.
recommended_action: Rotate all API keys found in this file immediately.
Add backend/.env to .gitignore if not present.
Consider rewriting history (BFG or git-filter-repo) if the secret was pushed to remote and a full purge is required.

counts_estimate.note: The backend folder contains a massive number of duplicate/archival files. Exact per-file counts can be produced on request (this may take time).

next_steps: If you want an exact per-file literal list (every file annotated), reply and I'll expand the classification into a full file-to-action JSON (warning: very large).
Alternatively we can move candidates to `backend/_archive/` in a cleanup branch (non-destructive) and then run quick validation.
I recommend immediate removal from git of `backend/.env` and rotation of secrets.
